awd_titl_txt: US Ignite: Collaborative Research: Focus Area 2: Resilient Virtual Path Management for Scalable Data-intensive Computing at Network-Edges
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses bootstrapping and managing virtual path networks hosting Visual Cloud Computing (VCC) applications for public safety during disaster incidents.  This project meets the needs of incident-supporting VCC applications that are essential for first responders to gain rapid visual situational awareness through: (a) scalable processing of imagery/video data collected at incident scenes, and (b) use of thin-client technologies for collaboration. Targeted demonstrations will also be conducted in collaboration with first-responder agencies such as trauma care hospitals (with theater-scale use cases) and a county fire protection district (with regional-scale use cases).  Specifically, the project objectives are to: (i) investigate virtual path management algorithms and large-scale simulations with the aim of providing resilient VCC applications with guaranteed performance even in the presence of host/link failures, host mobility and network partitioning; and (ii) demonstrate resilient resource provisioning for such path management algorithms within hybrid fog-cloud infrastructures on experimental testbeds such as GENI and CloudLab.

The salient theoretical contribution of this project lays in the design of novel distributed and federated algorithms for the virtual path embedding and computation placement problems, for real-time VCC applications. In particular, the project seeks a solution improvement for constrained path finders schemes, e.g., virtual network embedding or traffic steering, in presence of severe host and link failures, host mobility and network partitioning. The work also advances knowledge of application-aware network design through a scheme that allows fog-cloud compute location selection tradeoffs. In particular, the approach is based on decoupling small/large instances of visual data processing in the context of latency-critical VCC applications at:  (a) "theater-scale" for first-responder and incident commander personnel co-ordination at an incident scene, and (b) "regional-scale" for tracking objects of interest across different geographical scales in wide-area motion imagery from airborne platforms.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we investigate how computer networks can be managed and made more resilient to failures in preparation or response to emergency responses due to natural disasters or other incident applications. We proposed a network management application improving network management mechanisms for both virtual network creation (solving constrained graph embedding problems) and maintenance (solving virtual network adaptation problems). The goals have been to allow: (a) data import from the network edge (with civilian smartphones and surveillance cameras) to pertinent computing sites (e.g., edge clouds, fogs, or public cloud) and (b) further providing situational awareness to the responder sites with satisfactory user Quality of Experience. Both these processes are variations of a procedure that in edge computing jargon is referred to as offloading.

The virtual network path management mechanisms that we proposed were motivated by emerging paradigms such as software-defined networking, network function virtualization, and hybrid cloud computing, which allow the decoupling of the network/system1 elements and their functions to realize scalable computation and networking elasticity.

This project had several research objectives. At the application level, our goal has been to integrate computer vision and other applications to support first responders. At the infrastructure level, we proposed improvements within the whole virtual network lifetime. Specifically, we improved the effectiveness of edge computing solutions with resilient offloading techniques and resilient virtual path management solutions. The proposed work resulted in results published with several international collaborators in venues spanning computer networks and edge computing. In particular, our research outcomes can be summarized as follows:

Outcome 1: We investigated resilient virtual path management algorithms with rigorous complexity analysis and large-scale simulations to provide guaranteed and resilient Quality of Service in the presence of host/link failures, host mobility, and computer network partitioning. We remark that such limitations and constraints would be typical post-disaster and our algorithms needed to handle them robustly. Algorithms were evaluated based on key performance metrics such as the ability to function and provide edge computing application services in the presence of various network topology changes and dynamic constraints such as overall allocation ratio, network utilization, and energy efficiency.

Outcome 2: We designed and implemented virtual network management algorithms in the context of edge computing applications on wide-area experimental testbeds (e.g., GENI or CloudLab) to demonstrate the improvement in the resilient resource provisioning within edge-cloud infrastructures. We explored graph-based abstraction techniques to enable (visual) applications to specify Quality of Service demands to our algorithms for effective disaster incident response. We then implemented our algorithms within experimental testbeds to estimate their impact, such as, e.g., frame rate and user Quality of Experience compared to other state-of-the-art approaches. 

Outcome 3: We prototyped systems from the above investigations and experimented how they can be effectively used as plug-ins within emerging edge cloud infrastructure environments, and we used these prototypes (whose code is linked within our publications) as educational materials in computer networks curriculum for hands-on training of undergraduate and graduate students.

As part of this project, the PI conducted research to support and improve the culture and climate in computer networks, training several undergraduate and graduate students. He participated in several initiatives to broaden and strengthen diversity in computer networks, including the involvement of underrepresented minorities. Two examples of minority students hired thanks to this project are an African-American woman recruited thanks to the McNair Scholar program running at Saint Louis University and a Hispanic-American undergraduate woman who spent a summer abroad doing research on the topic of this project with collaborators at the University of Bologna, Italy.
